Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Resilience and adaptive capacity of arctic marine systems under a changing climate (RACArctic)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 14-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum. The Belmont Forum is a high level group of the world's major and emerging funders of global environmental change research and international science councils. It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in this Collaborative Research Action, the partner agencies have provided support for research projects that utilize existing Arctic observing systems, datasets and models to evaluate key sustainability challenges and opportunities in the Arctic region, to innovate new sustainability science theory and approaches to these challenges and opportunities, and support decision-making towards a sustainable Arctic environment. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and end users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).

The RACArctic (Resilience and adaptive capacity of arctic marine systems under a changing climate) project will bring together a team of natural and social scientists from the US, Japan, and Norway to investigate stressors and futures of fisheries-impacted marine ecosystems in the north. Through a synthesis of available observations, including information from fisheries managers and subsistence harvesters, the team will assess the effects of physical drivers and human pressures on marine ecosystems and key fish populations in the North Atlantic and North Pacific. Best practices for fisheries management in these sectors will be developed from the available management frameworks taking into account not only physical-biological relationships but the adaptive capacity of fish stocks, the integrated ecosystem, and the socio-economic needs of fisheries-dependent communities in the Subarctic-Arctic transition zone. This comparative analysis will connect with a breadth of stakeholders through a series of workshops and provide use-inspired results through collaboration with fisheries management councils.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Climate change is more pronounced in the Arctic and has led to a loss of sea ice, warmer ocean temperatures, and more corrosive waters. However, the impacts of these changes on marine ecosystems, including fish populations, fisheries, and the communities that depend on them are poorly understood. Therefore, this collaborative research project on the Resilience and Adaptive Capacity of Arctic Marine Systems under a Changing Climate (RACArctic) developed a set of plausible scenarios for future change that were presented to stakeholders to explore opportunities, threats and options for adaptation. These form the basis for recommendations to improve the resilience of fishery management institutions across the three participating countries: Japan, Norway and the United States.

Approach: We held a series of three workshops, one in each of the collaborating countries. Each workshop consisted of a one-day stakeholder workshop and two days of scientific workshops. The stakeholder meetings included presentations of plausible scenarios of future changes in Arctic marine ecosystems based on the best current scientific understanding. Our focus was on the major Arctic inflow shelves (Bering Sea and Chukchi Sea in the Pacific; Barents Sea and Fram Strait in the Atlantic), which support large commercial fisheries and rich subsistence resources. The scenarios, which were developed and refined during the scientific portions of the workshops, formed the basis for open discussions among stakeholders to identify their needs and concerns in a rapidly changing Arctic.

Outcomes: Stakeholder meetings resulted in a shared understanding that ocean management in these productive high-latitude regions needs to adapt to fast-changing ocean conditions. This has become especially urgent as recent changes have outpaced our expectations from just a few years ago. Some examples of consequential changes include (1) the ?Borealization? of both the Pacific and Atlantic inflow shelves, which describes the northward expansion of boreal (=temperate or southern) species and the replacement of Arctic species as the ice melts earlier and ocean temperatures increase; (2) increased primary production in areas that were formerly ice-covered for a much longer period. These areas now support large populations of boreal fishes that migrate to the newly ice-free areas to take advantage of increased prey availability; (3) declining abundances of the globally important stock of walleye pollock in the southeastern Bering Sea due to changes in prey availability associated with changing ice conditions; (4) the increasing frequency of harmful algal blooms due to warming waters; and (5) disruptions to established patterns of subsistence harvests due to later ice formation or lack of ice in the northern Bering Sea and Chukchi Sea.

These and other changes in the Arctic inflow shelves were summarized in two synthesis papers that focus on physical / chemical changes and biological responses, respectively, and will be published as a special section in the ICES Journal of Marine Science. A third paper focuses on the research and management implications; some preliminary conclusions are that (1) expanded monitoring and new scientific approaches are essential to our ability to rapidly respond to inevitable environmental changes; (2) ecosystem-based management approaches across multiple species need to be further developed to better manage changing systems; (3) shifting fish stocks will require new international cooperation for some key species such as walleye pollock and Pacific cod in the Bering Sea; (4) market impacts on local fisheries need to be considered along with biological changes and (5) flexible management that minimizes unnecessary temporal, spatial, or targeting restrictions provides greater and more cost-effective adaptation options.

In addition to synthesizing a large body of literature on changing marine ecosystems to better inform scientists and managers, our project provided other intangible benefits by bringing together scientists from multiple disciplines across the natural scientists and social scientists, as well as stakeholders from the shipping industry, fishing industry and other marine-dependent communities. The project has contributed to improved communication across disciplines and cultures, providing training and practice in both trans-disciplinary and trans-cultural communication. The stakeholder workshops have led to a shared understanding of changing marine systems in Alaska, Japan and Norway and have helped scientists better understand the concerns and needs of stakeholders that depend on these regions for their livelihood. Findings from the project have been widely disseminated, including to fisheries management organizations as a number of PIs in each of the countires serve on relevant scientific advisory bodies.
